abstracts.cdata!:
The overall outcome rating of the West
            African Gas Pipeline Project for Ghana was judged to be
            moderately satisfactory. The Bank and borrower performance
            ratings were moderately satisfactory. The risk to
            development outcome was moderate.  Several lessons were
            learned.  For cross-border energy projects, both supply-side
            and demand side risks need to be carefully assessed and
            their potential impact quantified. Risk analysis should
            typically go beyond those faced by the private partners, and
            should focus directly on the specific risks to the project
            development objectives.  Careful assessment of political,
            community, and social issues in large infrastructure
            investments should be considered and identified and
            adequately taken into account. The institutional framework
            for large multi-country projects, like the West African Gas
            Pipeline (WAGP), requires a careful balancing of interests
            and responsibilities of different stakeholders. The risks,
            responsibilities and incentives of all these stakeholders
            need to be appropriately allocated for the success of the
            project. The scope and conduct of supervision of a
            transformational regional project should be comprehensive
            regardless of the instrument used and amount of Bank
            support. Economic and financial evaluations should assume a
            wider range of commodity prices and other variables. Capital
            intensive, cross-border energy infrastructure projects
            should have stronger commercial underpinnings. The WAGP was
            conceived as an Economic Community of West African States
            initiative, with Nigeria playing a dominant role in
            exporting natural gas to its smaller neighbors in the
            region. The project, therefore, had strong regional
            political support. However, while an elaborate contractual
            framework was developed, the commercial provisions were
            rarely enforced by the signing parties. At the time of
            project sanction, WAGP prices were very attractive relative
            to domestic process. The main lesson is that upstream gas
            prices should be structured so that gas exports maintain
            their competitiveness vis-a-vis competing domestic sales.
